introduction.p: When we solve an equation such as 2+3x=17 we find a value for the variable that makes the equation true. The solution to this equation is 5, because the two expressions 2+3x and 17 are equal if x=5. If we use any other value for x, say x=9 or x=-1, then 2+3x does not equal 17.

It is possible for two algebraic expressions to be equal for all values of the variable. For instance, the expressions 2x+3x and 5x will always give the same value when the same number is substituted for x in each expression. For example, \text{if}~~x=\alert{3}~~~~~\text{then}~~~~~~2x+3x \amp =2(\alert{3})+3(\alert{3}) \amp = 6+9=15 \text{and}~~~~~~5x \amp = 5(\alert{3})=15 Both expressions equal 15 when x=3.

assemblage.title: Equivalent Expressions
assemblage.p: Two algebraic expressions are equivalentequivalent if they name the same number for all values of the variable.

introduction.p: Thus, 2+3x and 5x are equivalent expressions, and we can replace one by the other if it will simplify our work.

warning.p: Although two expressions may name the same number for some values of the variable, they are not necessarily equivalent. For example, to show that the expressions 2+3x and 5x are not equivalent, we only have to find a single value of x for which they are not equal. If we evaluate each expression for x=6, we find: 2+3x \amp = 2+3(\alert{6})=20 5x \amp = 5(\alert{6})=30 Because they are not equal for x=6, the expressions 2+3x and 5x are not equivalent.

answer.p: When they name the same number for all values of the variable.

subsection.title: Like Terms
subsection.p: We saw above that 2x+3x and 5x are equivalent expressions. This makes sense when we consider what these expressions mean: 2x means two x's added together, and 3x means three x's added together. Then 2x+3x=(x+x)+(x+x+x)=5x We can add two x's to three x's and get five x's, just as we can add two pencils to three pencils, or two dollars to three dollars. In algebra this is called combining like termscombining like termscombining like termslike terms.

assemblage.title: Like Terms
assemblage.p: Like terms are any terms that are exactly alike in their variable factors.

assemblage.title: Numerical Coefficient
assemblage.p: The numerical factor factor in a term is called the numerical coefficient, or just the coefficient of the term.

ol.label: a
ol.li: In the expression 3xy, the number 3 is the numerical coefficient.
In a term such as xy or b, the numerical coefficient is 1.
If a variable is preceded by a negative sign, the coefficient of the term is -1. For example, -x~~~~~~\text{means}~~~~~~ \amp -1 \cdot x -a~~~~~~\text{means}~~~~~~ \amp -1 \cdot a

assemblage.title: To add like terms
assemblage.p: Add the numerical coefficients of the terms. Do not change the variable factors of the terms.

assemblage.title: Look Ahead

assemblage.title: Simplifying an expression
assemblage.p: Replacing an expression by a simpler equivalent one is called simplifying the expression.

introduction.p: We subtract like terms in the same way that we add like terms.

assemblage.title: To subtract like terms
assemblage.p: Subtract the numerical coefficients of the terms. Do not change the variable factors of the terms.

statement.p: How do we add or subtract like terms?

answer.p: Add or subtract the numerical coefficients of the terms.

subsubsection.p: Many expressions contain both like and unlike terms. In such expressions we can combine only the like terms.

solution.p: We combine all the a-terms, and all the constant terms, like this: -4a+8a+5a=9a ~~~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~~~2-5=-3 so -4a+2-5+8a+5a=9a-3

warning.p: In , 9a-3 \not= 6a, because 9a and -3 are not like terms.

introduction.p: When we add signed numbers, we can remove parentheses that follow an addition symbol. For instance, 5+(-3)=5-3=2 We can also remove parentheses when we add like terms. Thus, 5x+(-3x)=5x-3x=2x

assemblage.title: Removing parentheses that follow a plus sign
assemblage.p: Parentheses preceded by a plus sign may be omitted, and each term within parentheses keeps its original sign.

assemblage.title: Removing parentheses that follow a minus sign
assemblage.p: If an expression inside parentheses is preceded by a minus sign, we change the sign of each term within parentheses and then omit the parentheses and the minus sign.

solution.p: Before combining like terms, we must remove the parentheses. We change the signs of any terms inside parentheses preceded by a minus sign; we do not change the signs of terms inside parentheses preceded by a plus sign.

answer.p: Change the sign of each term within parentheses.
